prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 1
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 2
Name: Bronco Knight
Description: A former bodyguard who killed his team leader. He is set to stand trial soon.
Character 3
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A defense attorney I have known for a long time, but haven't seen in years. Apparently, he lived abroad for a while.
Character 4
Name: Rocco Carcerato
Description: An inmate and former boxer who is obsessed with training. Has a pet polar bear named Teddy.
Character 5
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 6
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: A rookie prosecutor who's taken over my cases on the Committee's orders.
Character 7
Name: Simeon Saint
Description: The suspect in this case. A timid young man who seems an unlikely murderer.
Character 8
Name: Fifi Laguarde
Description: Warden of the prison. An animal lover who considers physical contact to be very important.
Character 9
Name: Frank Sahwit
Description: The prison inmate who first discovered the body. Currently training to be a pet stylist.
Character 10
Name: Bodhidharma Kanis
Description: A blind ex-assassin whose favored tools were a black dog and a knife. The tinkling of small bells used to accompany his appearance.
Character 11
Name: Shi-Long Lang
Description: An Interpol agent with an unrivaled arrest rate. Originally from Zheng Fa.
Character 12
Name: Regina Berry
Description: Head animal trainer at the Berry Big Circus, and Saint's boss.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 1
Name: Building Layout
Description: A map of the facility, including the detention center and the prison proper.
Evidence 2
Name: Mr. Knight's Body
Description: Cause of death: Stab wound to the throat. Death would have been instant. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. [info] The victim had a ring on his right hand, which was covered by a sheet when the body was discovered.  Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. The body is covered in dirt. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. Killed instantly by a stab wound to the throat. There is also a small cut on his scalp from when he suffered a blow to the head. A sweet scent can be detected.
Evidence 3
Name: Pocket Chess Set
Description: A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It appears to have belonged to the victim. A folding chessboard with the pieces stored inside. It belonged to Knight, and was brought to him at his request by Saint. Portable folding chessboard. Belonged to Knight. There is a hidden space inside the chessboard. Knight hid a chisel in here to prevent it from being found by the prison staff.
Evidence 4
Name: Rubber Glove
Description: Only one glove was found at the crime scene. Prison-issued equipment for working inmates. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Used by Sahwit when he was doing his animal styling training. Stained with blood and mud. Found in Workshop A. Sullied after being worn by Sahwit when administering a dark mudpack treatment. Also bloodstained.
Evidence 5
Name: Rope
Description: Discovered on top of Knight's body. Does this mean the victim was tied up?
Evidence 6
Name: Bloodstained Sheet
Description: Colorful tarp found by the victim's body. Some of these were being stored in Workshop A.
Evidence 7
Name: Door Sensor
Description: Fitted to each workshop's door, they detect and react to the prisoners' bracelets when they are near by raising the alarm. They open the doors if an animal is detected, but raise the alarm if an inmate's bracelet is detected. Prisoners are not allowed to move about freely.
Evidence 8
Name: Prison Roll Call
Description: Held three times a day: 7 AM, noon, and 9 PM. The victim's body had not been found at the time of the 7 AM roll call.
Evidence 9
Name: Black Dog
Description: Sahwit claims to have seen this dog biting the victim's throat. He doesn't seem to like me very much.
Evidence 10
Name: Sahwit's Bracelet
Description: Sahwit's bracelet is broken, and can no longer be detected by the prison's sensors. Sahwit's bracelet wasn't working at the time of the incident, and could not be detected by the sensors.
Evidence 11
Name: Dog Chess Piece
Description: Carved for fun by Kanis. He also seems to be engaged in correspondence chess via postal mail.
Evidence 12
Name: Prison Search
Description: Winner, Gavèlle and the warden searched the prison for the murder weapon, but couldn't find anything.
Evidence 13
Name: Wiped Floor
Description: There are signs that the floor in the victim's detention center cell was wiped clean. There are signs that the floor in the victim's cell was wiped clean. I've ordered a test to see if it was blood. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. We're currently checking whose blood it is. There are signs that blood was wiped from the floor of the victim's cell. The blood has been confirmed as Knight's.
Evidence 14
Name: Chess Diagram
Description: The positions of the pieces match those on the board in Kanis's cell. Knight was playing correspondence chess against Kanis. Did the two have some sort of connection?
Evidence 15
Name: Security Camera Footage
Description: Footage of a detention center holding cell showing the victim being attacked by a dark form. The time stamp is off due to a three-hour gap in the footage. This was actually recorded around 9 AM.
Evidence 16
Name: Missing Guard Uniform
Description: Stolen from a guard's locker in the detention center corridor on March 26th.
Evidence 17
Name: Mr. Knight's Cell Key
Description: A guard was attacked and his keys, including the one to Knight's cell, were stolen. They have yet to be recovered. A guard was attacked the day before the murder, and his keys were stolen. They were found in Carcerato's possession.
Evidence 18
Name: Security Gates
Description: Deployed at the entrances to both the detention center and the prison proper. Capable of detecting items made of metal.
Evidence 19
Name: Tunnel Prints
Description: A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. It seems to depict the paw prints of a dog. A photo of the tunnel between the prison and the detention center. Shows paw prints made by a bear.
Evidence 20
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The interim report suggests that the cause of death was a stab wound to the neck, inflicted by a sharp blade. Death was instantaneous. Estimated time of death is between 3 AM and 6 AM on the 27th. Instant death from a stab wound to the neck.
Evidence 21
Name: Chisel
Description: Contains traces of blood. Hidden by Kanis inside his dog's mouth. Has a small bell attached to it. Belonged to Knight. Hidden by Kanis in Helmut's mouth in order to avoid suspicion.
Evidence 22
Name: Mr. Kanis's Bells
Description: Only two such bells exist. One is attached to Helmut the dog, the other to Kanis's knife, which was seized by the police during his arrest.
Evidence 23
Name: Mr. Saint's Trick
Description: A contraption that used the well, a very heavy weight, three pulleys, and two lengths of rope to send Saint flying during the show. Used during the show to send Saint flying. The weights were replaced with the victim's body by someone.
Evidence 24
Name: Breakers
Description: Located in the power room, just off the prison yard. Were they tampered with the night before the body was found?

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Recreation time ended around 10 AM.
Person: Elbird
Testimony 1
Testimony: I returned to this room and went straight to my training.
Person: Elbird
Testimony 2
Testimony: Just as I'd counted to two, I heard a voice shout out, "AAARGH! I've been stabbed!"
Person: Elbird
Testimony 3
Testimony: It sounded like someone in pain, calling out for help. But...
Person: Elbird
Testimony 4
Testimony: I couldn't do anything since I was locked up in my cell. So, I went back to my training.
Person: Elbird

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. I'll start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony one by one and see where there might be a conflict.

First, looking at the evidence:

Evidence 0: Prosecutor's Badge. Doesn't seem to conflict with any testimonies directly.

Evidence 1: Building Layout. Again, not directly conflicting with testimonies.

Evidence 2: Mr. Knight's Body. The description mentions that the body was covered by a sheet, and there's a sweet scent. Also, the victim had a ring on his right hand, which was covered by a sheet when the body was discovered. This might be important.

Evidence 3: Pocket Chess Set. Belongs to Knight and has a hidden chisel. Not directly conflicting.

Evidence 4: Rubber Glove. Found in Workshop A, used by Sahwit. Bloodstained and mudstained.

Evidence 5: Rope. Found on top of Knight's body. Maybe he was tied up.

Evidence 6: Bloodstained Sheet. Found by the body, some stored in Workshop A.

Evidence 7: Door Sensor. Reacts to prisoners' bracelets and animals. If someone's bracelet is detected, it raises an alarm.

Evidence 8: Prison Roll Call. Held at 7 AM, noon, and 9 PM. The body wasn't found at 7 AM roll call, meaning the murder happened after that.

Evidence 9: Black Dog. Sahwit claims he saw a black dog biting Knight's throat. Sahwit doesn't like the prosecutor.

Evidence 10: Sahwit's Bracelet. It's broken and couldn't be detected by sensors. So, Sahwit's bracelet wasn't working during the incident.

Evidence 11: Dog Chess Piece. Carved by Kanis. Not conflicting.

Evidence 12: Prison Search. No weapon found.

Evidence 13: Wiped Floor. Blood wiped from Knight's cell, confirmed as his.

Evidence 14: Chess Diagram. Matches Kanis's cell. Maybe a connection between them.

Evidence 15: Security Camera Footage. Shows Knight being attacked by a dark form, timestamp is off by 3 hours, actual time around 9 AM.

Evidence 16: Missing Guard Uniform. Stolen on March 26th.

Evidence 17: Mr. Knight's Cell Key. Stolen from a guard, found in Carcerato's possession.

Evidence 18: Security Gates. Detect metal items.

Evidence 19: Tunnel Prints. Shows paw prints of a bear.

Evidence 20: Autopsy Report. Death between 3 AM and 6 AM on 27th.

Evidence 21: Chisel. Blood traces, hidden in a dog's mouth.

Evidence 22: Kanis's Bells. Only two exist, attached to dog and knife.

Evidence 23: Saint's Trick. Used to send Saint flying, weights replaced with Knight's body.

Evidence 24: Breakers. Tampered with the night before.

Now, looking at the testimonies:

Testimony 0: Elbird says recreation time ended around 10 AM.

Testimony 1: Elbird returned to his room and went straight to training.

Testimony 2: Elbird heard a shout at "AAARGH! I've been stabbed!" when he counted to two.

Testimony 3: It sounded like someone in pain, but...

Testimony 4: He couldn't do anything since locked in cell, so went back to training.

Wait, let's see. Testimony 2 says Elbird heard a shout when he counted to two. But when? If recreation ended at 10 AM (Testimony 0), and Elbird went to training (Testimony 1), then the shout happened during his training. But the autopsy report (Evidence 20) says the death was between 3 AM and 6 AM, which is much earlier than 10 AM. So Elbird's testimony about hearing the shout at 10 AM contradicts the autopsy report's time of death.

Another point: Evidence 15 mentions security footage showing the attack around 9 AM, but the timestamp was off by 3 hours. So actual time was 9 AM, but the autopsy says death was between 3 AM and 6 AM. That's a contradiction between Evidence 15 and Evidence 20.

Wait, but the user asked for one pair. Let's see:

Testimony 2 says Elbird heard the shout when he counted to two. If recreation ended at 10 AM, and he started training, then the shout was around 10 AM. But the autopsy says death was between 3 AM and 6 AM. So the timing is conflicting.

So the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (hearing the shout at 10 AM) and Evidence 20 (death between 3-6 AM).

Alternatively, Testimony 2 might be referring to a different event, but the timing seems off.

Another possible contradiction: Evidence 15's footage shows the attack at 9 AM, but the timestamp is off by 3 hours, so actual time was 9 AM, but the autopsy says death was between 3-6 AM. So that's a contradiction between Evidence 15 and Evidence 20.

But the user wants one pair, so perhaps the most direct contradiction is between Testimony 2 (hearing the shout at 10 AM) and Evidence 20 (death between 3-6 AM). Alternatively, between Evidence 15 and Evidence 20.

Wait, but the question is about evidence and testimony contradicting each other, not evidence and evidence.

So Testimony 2 says Elbird heard the shout at 10 AM, but Evidence 20 says death was between 3-6 AM. So they contradict because the shout (which would be the time of death) was heard at 10 AM, but the autopsy says it was earlier.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 might not necessarily be the time of death, but just a shout. But the autopsy says the death was between 3-6 AM, so if Elbird heard the shout at 10 AM, that's after the death, which is impossible because the person was already dead.

Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 20.

Another possibility: Evidence 15's footage was recorded around 9 AM, but the autopsy says death was between 3-6 AM. So that's a contradiction between Evidence 15 and Evidence 20.

But the question is about evidence and testimony, not evidence and evidence. So the pair would be Testimony 2 and Evidence 20.

Wait, but Testimony 2 is about hearing the shout, not the time of death. However, if the shout was at 10 AM, but the death was before 6 AM, that's a contradiction because the person couldn't shout after being dead.

So the pair is Testimony 2 and Evidence 20.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 and Evidence 15: because Evidence 15 shows the attack at 9 AM (after correction), but Testimony 2 says the shout was at 10 AM. But that's not a direct contradiction because the attack could have happened at 9, and the shout at 10, but that's possible if the victim survived for a bit. However, the autopsy says death was instantaneous, so the shout would have been at the time of the attack, which was 9 AM, but Testimony 2 says it was at 10 AM, which is a contradiction.

So the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 15.

Wait, but the user's question is to find one pair where evidence and testimony contradict each other. So I think the main contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 20, because Testimony 2 says the shout was heard at 10 AM, implying the death was then, but Evidence 20 says death was between 3-6 AM.

Alternatively, between Testimony 2 and Evidence 15, because the footage shows the attack at 9 AM (after correction), but Testimony 2 says the shout was at 10 AM, which is inconsistent.

But I'm a bit confused. Let me re-examine:

- Testimony 2: Elbird heard the shout when he counted to two. He was in training after recreation ended at 10 AM (Testimony 0). So the shout was at 10 AM.

- Evidence 15: Footage shows the attack at 9 AM (after correction), so the death was at 9 AM.

- Evidence 20: Death was between 3-6 AM.

So both Evidence 15 and Evidence 20 contradict each other, but the user wants evidence and testimony.

So Testimony 2 says the shout was at 10 AM, but Evidence 20 says death was before 6 AM. So Testimony 2 and Evidence 20 contradict.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 and Evidence 15: because Testimony 2 says the shout was at 10 AM, but Evidence 15 shows the attack at 9 AM. So the shout should have been at 9 AM, not 10.

So which pair is correct? I think Testimony 2 and Evidence 20 is the contradiction because the time of death is before 6 AM, but the shout was heard at 10 AM, which is impossible.

So the answer would be Testimony 2 and Evidence 20.
</think>

Testimony 0
Testimony: I was in the workroom over there practicing my skills.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 1
Testimony: By some chance, I got curious about the adjacent workroom, and went up to the door.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 2
Testimony: I peeked in through the small window on the door.
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 3
Testimony: Then I saw him lying there... A man... not moving... dead!
Person: Sahwit
Testimony 4
Testimony: I quailed in fright and found myself letting out a scream.

cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. First, I'll go through each piece of evidence and testimony to understand what they say and see if there's any inconsistency.

Looking at the evidence, number 20 is the Autopsy Report. It states that the cause of death was a stab wound to the neck, and the estimated time of death is between 3 AM and 6 AM on the 27th. This means the murder happened early in the morning before 7 AM.

Now, looking at the testimonies, specifically testimony 3 by Sahwit. He says he discovered the body when he peeked through a window and saw the man lying dead. The roll call at 7 AM didn't find the body, so the murder must have happened after that. But according to the Autopsy Report, the death was between 3 AM and 6 AM, which is before the 7 AM roll call.

This creates a contradiction because if Sahwit found the body after 7 AM, but the autopsy says the death was before 7 AM, there's a conflict in the timeline. The evidence suggests the body was already dead before the roll call, but the testimony implies Sahwit was the first to discover it after the roll call.

So, the contradiction is between Evidence 20 (Autopsy Report) and Testimony 3 (Sahwit's discovery).
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony one by one.

First, looking at the testimonies from Sahwit. He's the one who discovered the body, so his statements are crucial. In Testimony 0, he mentions a technique where prisoners can step out without sounding the alarm by keeping their bracelet in the room. This suggests that Sahwit might have been able to move around without being detected. In Testimony 1, he explains that by keeping his bracelet in the room, he could peek into the adjacent room, which he did in Testimony 2. He saw Knight dead and screamed, then in Testimony 4, he claims he saw a black dog biting Knight's neck. Testimony 5 adds that Knight was already dead, and Testimony 6 mentions a ring with a snowflake insignia.

Now, looking at the evidence. Evidence 10 talks about Sahwit's bracelet being broken and not detected by the sensors. This means Sahwit couldn't have been detected by the door sensors because his bracelet wasn't working. However, Sahwit's testimonies suggest he used a technique to move around without being detected, which might not be possible if his bracelet was broken because the sensors wouldn't recognize him at all. If his bracelet was broken, he wouldn't need to keep it in the room to avoid detection. This creates a contradiction because if his bracelet wasn't working, the technique he described wouldn't apply, and his ability to move undetected might be in question.

Another point is Evidence 2, which describes the body. It mentions a sweet scent, which might relate to the ring Sahwit saw. However, the main contradiction is between Sahwit's testimonies about using his bracelet to avoid detection and the fact that his bracelet was broken, making the technique irrelevant.

So, the contradiction is between Testimony 1, where Sahwit describes using his bracelet to stay undetected, and Evidence 10, which states his bracelet was broken and couldn't be detected. This means he couldn't have used the technique as described because the bracelet wasn't functional.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by going through the evidence and testimonies one by one to spot any inconsistencies.

First, looking at the evidence, there are several items that stand out. Evidence 3 is the Pocket Chess Set, which belonged to Knight and was brought to him by Saint. It also mentions that there's a hidden space inside the chessboard where Knight hid a chisel to avoid detection by prison staff. Evidence 14 is the Chess Diagram, which shows the positions of the pieces matching those in Kanis's cell, suggesting that Knight was playing correspondence chess against Kanis.

Now, looking at the testimonies, Debeste claims that the victim's chessboard had fingerprints that only belonged to Simeon Saint, the victim, and the guards. Specifically, Testimony 3 states, "The victim carried a chessboard. From it, we found Simeon Saint's fingerprints." This implies that the chessboard was handled by Saint, which would mean he had access to it.

However, according to Evidence 3, the chessboard was in Knight's possession and was brought to him by Saint. This means that Saint would have had to handle the chessboard to bring it to Knight. If the chessboard was indeed in Knight's cell, it's reasonable to assume that Knight's fingerprints would be on it. But Debeste's testimony only mentions the victim (Knight), Saint, and the guards, which aligns with the fact that Knight owned the chessboard and Saint delivered it.

Wait, but Evidence 3 also mentions that the chessboard had a hidden space where a chisel was stored. If the chessboard was in Knight's cell, and Kanis was playing correspondence chess with Knight, then Kanis might have also handled the chessboard. But Debeste's testimony doesn't mention Kanis's fingerprints. This could be a point of contradiction because if Kanis was involved in the chess game, his fingerprints should also be on the chessboard.

Another point to consider is that the chisel hidden inside the chessboard was used as the murder weapon, as indicated by Evidence 21. If the chisel was hidden by Kanis, then Kanis must have had access to the chessboard, which would mean his fingerprints should be present. However, Debeste's testimony only mentions Saint, Knight, and the guards, omitting Kanis.

Therefore, the contradiction arises between Testimony 3 and Evidence 14. The testimony claims that only Knight, Saint, and the guards' fingerprints were on the chessboard, but the evidence suggests that Kanis was also involved through the chess correspondence, implying his fingerprints should be present as well.
